reviewText:
In this review I'll be covering the story, objectives and tone of this great game.

Story
You emerge as a citizen, trapped inside an abandoned home that you now know as safety, along with two or three other people; you've been stuck between war zones where survival and horror cross fade. You are not a soldier and therefore just a survivor. Searching ruble left behind by shelling finding few scraps of food and items. You find cloth to bandage your friends wounds in and antibiotics to help your sickness. You find little useful materials and components to build with, but is enough for a simple hotplate and a makeshift bed to rest bloodied limbs on. You know you can't survive with what you have, you know you need more supplies, but you also know you can't just walk outside with snipers lurking. You wait for night, where you'll travel for supplies in an effort for not just yourself, but the survival of your comrades as well. Risking everything you know you'll have to choose between life or death, starvation or robbery and kindness or murder. There is no choices, only decisions.

Objectives
You play as one or more survivors at once, controlling their separate thoughts and decisions. 'This War of Mine' plays like 'The Sims' in a dark horrible way. In order to eat out of your fridge, you must either scavenge for food, steal for it or kill for it. Sometimes you have a choice, others you don't. This game is all about choosing between ultimately life or death.
During the day you play as all the characters working towards fixing, improving your safety and health. You need to eat, drink (is automatic), sleep, heal and improvise along with catering to character specific needs such as smoking or drinking coffee. Sometimes you have people during the day that try to trade with you, where you can use your found items to trade with theirs for things you need. Other times you have people whom seek help, medical or physical; good or bad. Once nightfall reaches you have two choices, to stay, or scavenge; by choosing what each persons role for the night is. After this, it's your time to shine, you can scavenge, steal or kill for things such as food, materials, supplies and items.
The games pace is repetitive, but the shear pain and suffering to see your characters go through is what compels you to continue, to see hope or a light. Once you come home you can talk to others about your findings, reassure them that you'll survive, offer them food or medical attention. Once you have your resources, it is yours to use it wisely. Just remember, that you're not alone, your death is likely likewise having your own safety attacked and looted from. This game is all about survival, and it shows just that in all the most brutal ways possible during war...

Tone and Emotions
You as the player, will feel the pain and suffering your characters go through. Murdering people feels bad and so does robbing people of their supplies. When your characters feel bad whether its from woundings or from being depressed. You'll feel it with them. 'This War of Mine] is a harsh game in all ways, and there is no running from it. When a character leaves due to how they feel, or when a character dies because you couldn't do enough; you feel the weight on your shoulders, the sadness and emotions of the other occupants you still have to survive for. This games takes your point of view about war into a whole new perspective, and it is harsh.

Pros and Cons
Overall I think that this is a genuinly great game, it has been a long time where just the gameplay makes me sad or that I feel bad stealing or killing others. Certainly deserves a close look. This concludes my review, I may visit this again if I have things to add.            Pros        Cons                    Immersive experience
Brutally honest war
Character emotions are in depth
Scavenging and robbing is great
Stealth is spot on
Inventory system is great
Building and upgrading system is spectacular
Character management is beautiful
Storyline is great
Mechanics overall are pleasing
Music and ambiance is nicely fitting
Graphics are really nice            Wish there were sidescroller controls such as WSAD or arrow keys
Having muti-people scavenging isn't implemented where honestly I would love it
There is no Co-op which would fit really nice with this game
Is repetitive but nice if you understand the story well
Not too many things to build, wish there were things like pool tables or having tables to eat at.
Just more objects and items to build in general. (Hint hint developers, bunk beds would be awesome!)

reviewText:
Oh my, where to begin?

This War of Mine places your small group of survivors in a run down building for the duration of a war that's taking place as a setting in the background. You and your companions are victims of circumstance and don't actually affect the outcome of the war or take part in it, you're merely trying to survive. The game frequently asks you to make difficult decisions in order to survive. To what lengths will you go to keep yourself and your friends alive?

This War of Mine is a bleak game and very moody. If I had to boil the game down to a gameplay description, I'd say that This War of Mine is a resource and risk management game with survival and stealth elements, base building, worker placement, and heavy theme; but it's so much more than that. Every decision you make comes at a cost. Everything you build costs resources and your nightly scavenging excursions can only bring back so much. Do you build a bed for everyone, or do you hot rack and sleep in shifts? Should you trade your medicine since it's worth a LOT, or do you give it to Katia, who is developing a cold that may get worse?

I knew this game had a hold on me the very first time I played it. Winter had set in by about day 30 or so and food had become even more scarce. We had resorted to trapping rats in our patched up house for a meager amount of meat every few days if we were lucky. Pavel, our best and agile scavenger, had been nearly killed while looking for supplies and it made the rest of us sad and scared. We had come to rely on him for bringing back what we needed every night.

This War of Mine starts with a random group of 3-4 survivors (randomized each time you start the game anew) each with different skills and potentially different vices as well. Some of the skills I have seen so far include 'good cook,' 'trained in combat,' and 'runs faster.' Some skills seem more useful than others and some I haven't found a use for yet (if there is one). The vices I have seen so far include 'coffee drinker' and 'smoker.' The vices affect a survivor's mood. This makes each playthrough different and challenging because you might end up with a very difficult spread of skills and vices to manage. The game also starts in a random season (hopefully not winter, good luck with that).

There is no handholding in This War of Mine, nor is there a tutorial. That said, I never felt like I needed one. The UI in TWoM is simple and effective, elegant even. You always know what you can interact with and how. There is a great deal of trial and error here, in a good way.

The game is separated into two phases, the day and the night cycle. During the day, you basically assign tasks to your survivors in real time (and the clock is running during this phase, but I wouldn't say you feel rushed by it; I've always had enough time to complete the goals I set). Maybe you want to build a still to produce liquor for trading (or consuming), or build a bed so you don't have to sleep on the floor. You'll do this in the day phase. Also during the day phase, a traveling trader might stop by to barter with you or a neighbor might come asking for help. You can choose to help or ignore these people. Sometimes people will show up asking to join your group. These are decisions you must weigh carefully, as they will be one more mouth to feed, one more person getting sick that needs medicine, etc. But they might also bring something valuable to the table, that is up to you to determine.

You can build a lot of different things in your shelter and everything you can build can also be upgraded with very few exceptions. Some of the things you can build include rainwater collectors, a radio (that works), a still, an herbal workshop for rolling cigarettes (to feed vices and also to trade), a metalworking table for making weapons and tools, and lots of other things.

When night falls, you are tasked with deciding who gets to sleep (and where), who should stand guard (if anyone), and who will go out to scavenge for supplies (and where). Other survivors can raid your shelter, so if no one stands guard, there's a good chance they will steal some of your things and this should be avoided at all costs as they can run off with a LOT of stuff if given the chance. Even if you have guards, there's always the chance they can be wounded in these raids. When you decide where to scavenge, you're given a set of locations to choose from, each with a description of what you might encounter there so you can come prepared. A bombed out school may indicate you should probably bring a shovel to dig through rubble piles more effectively. A military outpost may have goods for trade, or they may shoot on sight. There's always a risk everywhere you go. Available locations change over time, as well, with new locations opening up, and some closing due to the war or inclement weather. As far as I can tell, these are heavily randomized for the most part as well.

There is combat in the game, including stealth kills and a cover system that I have not experimented with too much yet as I try to avoid combat as much as possible (it's super deadly). Most tools can be used as weapons (crowbars, shovels, axes) and you can also find and repair firearms or trade for them occasionally, but ammunition is rare (but can also be crafted with the right facilities and components). Again though, what are you going to give up to be able to craft your own guns? Heat in the winter? A safe place to sleep?

I can't say enough good things about this game. It runs super smooth on my Linux computer and it hasn't crashed on me once. Top notch Linux port from War Child, I'm very impressed!

I paid 16,14€ for this game during Steam's Winter Sales and feel that you'll get your money's worth out of it. I've been playing it for almost 30 hours so far and I haven't grown bored of it yet.

reviewText: What a left turn This War of Mine is. 11 bit studios previously made the markedly un-serious Anomaly games, festivals of tactical explosions, air-strikes and all the other hoo-rah wargasms we’re generally exposed to. A sombre survival game exploring the vulnerability of civilians trapped in warzones wasn’t where I would have pegged them to go next.\n\nThese twists on the formula are where I’m finding my interest in survival games peaking. As Pip pointed out in her interview with senior writer Pawel Miechowski, it’s taking what zombies have long been a metaphor for and going literal. Now 11 bit have announced we’ll get to be war-torn on November 14th and thrown a trailer into the mix as well.

reviewText:
Let me first start off by saying - this game is BRUTAL.

Brutal meaning even when your survivors have enough food and supplies - they'll still get depressed if you don't have coffee for the mornings and cigarettes for the evenings. They might even kill themselves.

Brutal meaning if your survivors are starving to death and you choose to steal from some old people (still leaving some food and supplies for them),  your survivors will not be grateful, but instead have mental breakdowns and kill themselves.

Brutal meaning if one of your survivors gets injured whilst scavenging (but yet returns alive with the much-needed supplies), the remaining survivors will have mental breakdowns and kill themselves.

Brutal meaning even if one of your survivors (or more) sees the end of the war, but you had to resort to stealing or killing to survive, they'll just wind up in prison or on the streets. And they'll probably kill themselves.

Overall, I'd recommend This War of Mine. It's brutal. It's depressing. Such is war.

reviewText:
I didn't play 2D games last 10 years. After seeing and hearing all positive things and reviews about this game,i decided to give it a try.

This war of mine is really good game,although i'm not big fan of 2D. But still,i think 19€ is little bit too expensive price for this type of game.
There are some minor bugs,nothing scary or gamebraking,but i think it's unacceptable for 1GB to have any bugs 1 year after relase.
There is no tutorial in this game-few times my survivors died because i didn't know how combat system works.
Worst thing in This war of mine is scavenging- loot does not dissapear if you leave it over night,and that is really bad,bad and ultra bad thing in survival simulation game. If i leave jewelry and canned food IN FRIDGE IN CITY IN RUINS WHERE PEOPLE ARE STARVING,i'll find it again 5 night later.

Now to the good part.

Graphics are nice,and sound effects are amazing-it's probably best thing in this game.
This war of mine have huge number of different maps where various events can occur.
Crafting is very important for this game,and it is well done. It's interesting that you have to plan how you'll spent your aviable resources you bringed home.
Killing or stealing resources will have consequences that you'll have to deal with.
Each survivor have different set of skills.
You can create your own story,and this game is perfect for begginers like me to became familiar with Steam Workshop.

My overall score is 8/10

reviewText:
This is a nice game of resource management and taking chances. Although it is mostly skill that gets you through combative encounters, enough can go wrong with little mistake on your part to cause severe problems for you (such as a good character who is severely injured or killed).

There's enough meat to this game for you to want to read about the other characters and try to figure out which ones make for the best teams.

The save system is a bit brutal as it auto saves. So it's hard to run through the game correcting small mistakes with reloading. Instead, your small mistakes become game-long woes that you have to add to your list of problems you have to overcome.

There's also some strategy in the way you trade resources. For example, there's a vendor that sometimes shows up at your house and he is excellent to buy bulky but inexpensive construction materials from so you can save your scavenging inventory space for better things.

There is some variation in the levels you get and how they are initially set up. Some areas have guards placed in slightly different arrangements so that in one playthrough getting all the loot at some outpost is much easier than in another playthrough, but it is slight and not all zones have it (and typically they just have an either or setup and it isn't elabourate). It's a shame they didn't make more use of that mechanic.

One big con I had was, SPOILER ALERT, no bad guys ever came to your door. You would think since you're in the middle of a war that the invading army might show up at your place and like extort food or something from you or you'd have to fight in your own home to defend it or whatever. Kind of a shame since it would be cool to have the ability to plan out and build your defenses.

The game isn't very long and there's not a whole heck of a lot of replay to this game even though that seems odd considering it's a rogue like. But there's just a lot of boilerplate crap you need to get through in the beginning of a new game and things don't really heat up until quite a bit later...and then it's just one little mistake and you screw up your entire game and it autosaves and you throw your hands up and quit.

That's actually a pretty bad thing about the game. I mean, the sound and artwork is great for its theme. I'm so happy that this isn't about zombies even though it literally perfectly fits for that theme. I would love to see more skills and mechanics put into the game  and more interesting levels with more complicated puzzles or plots or character interactions bartering etc.

The somewhat variable time limit of the game is nice to keep things balanced, but it would be nice if I could just continue playing in a sandboxy mode or something. I don't know. I guess what I'm saying is I wish there was more...which usually means the game is worth a thumbs up, despite it's problems.

reviewText:
I would rate TWoM about a 7 out of 10 - This could easily be a 9 or even 10 out of 10 however I have to deduct some points for reasons listed below.

Procedural - Well... to be honest this game can only be called procedural with the barest bones of random elements. Dont be fooled into thinking every play through will be 'completely' different. There are approx 20 different locations you can scavenge and they always look the same. They have the same layout, cabinets etc are always in the same place. Only the contents vary somewhat (a cabinet may hold food and wood in one play and parts and wood in another). As to what will happen when you go there: every location has one of two possible events/scenarios at that location. Pretty barebones with the random element if you ask me...

Also survivors - There are basically 5 main survivors you can control, but they are always the same and have the same strengths/weaknesses every time.

Overall content - There just isnt enough that you can craft, harvest or build. Not by a long shot. No matter what 'random' scenario you have in your game you will always end up visiting the same locations in roughly the same order (by order of threat) and always building and upgrading the minimal amount of upgrades in roughly the same order of priority.

Despite the poor amount of overall content and procedural randomness I would still recommend this game (during a sale) as it shines when it comes down to gameplay and emotional attachment of characters. Some decisions you make can really weigh on your mind haha.

I havent really browsed the workshop as yet but this is one of those games that is very much worth playing, but could have been truly outstanding if it just had 'more'.

reviewText:
This game..

When I first saw This War Of Mine, I was pulled in by the idea of the tables being turned.. Rather than another FPS or something similar, this takes you into the lives of the people caught in the middle of hell. People who have to fight and scavenge off others who are just as poorly off, to survive a little while longer and perhaps make it through the war.

As I started playing, I thought by the looks of it, it isn't something I can hugely immerse myself into. How wrong I was.
On my second scavenging night, the paranoia of being caught, the anxiety of time not being on your side and the stress of needing to find as much stuff as possible to not have wasted a night is insane. By this time, I already was so drawn in that I felt connected with the group I had managed to keep alive for nearly 10 days, their light just barely alive. A while after, a person in my group, Bruno, died from severe wounds after we were robbed by force. The other two, were too broken to even move because they could no longer take it..

With no one left around to console them, it was over, I was done for. I had failed to keep my group alive, their regret of my choice to steal from other survivors breaking them further was too much.

This game, makes you question everything, and opens your eyes to the real hardships and horrors of war. War is a terrible, terrible thing in of itself, and this captures every piece of what it's like to be a poor survivor stuck in the middle perfectly. This war of mine is a tragic masterpiece and a horrible bit of art in every meaning of the word.

I cannot send enough praise to the developers way for capturing this so well.

reviewText: 11 bit studios 'This War of Mine' is a 2014 survival game.  Inspired by the 1992-96 Siege of Sarajevo during the Bosnia war, this game focuses on the civilian perspective of war, which differs to the normal military perspective.  The main goal of the game is to survive until the ceasefire, using the tools and materials the player can scavenge with the characters they are given.   Every action you decide to make will affect the survivors you are either given (if you play a developer-created story), or choose (if you play a custom story).  You are forced to make life-or-death deisions driven by your conscience constantly.  If you decide to kill, not only will your characters enter a time of depression, you (a general statement, those of you 'hardnuts' out there won't) will feel it too.\n\nGripping, emotional, borderline addictive.

reviewText:
I've had this game for a while and I still love it, which can't be said for a lot of games.

Not only are the visuals aesthetially pleasing, they also fit the theme of the game really well. Every single time I play, I go through every single emotion imaginable. The way individual events play with your heart and how each character has their own storyline and what makes it even better is that at the end, it's not an immediate cut off; you're told what happens to them after the ceasefire. This game is one of the most dramatic, exciting and heart wrenching games on the market and is worth every penny.

Not only that, there's an additional DLC that you can buy which adds artwork to the game and the money goes to charity (you can also decide how much you spend, to a certain extent).

However, there are a few things that I would like to see improved in the future as I believe it was touched on but not competely developed. Each character has a certain personality, explained in their biography. When certain events happen, their biography is updated with how they feel about the situation that happened, for example, if you choose to kill an NPC for supplies, some don't care while others actually do. What bothers me is that even though certain characters aren't affected by these, they still become sad, depressed and broken, leaving them completely useless. I would expect a character that actually understands the concept of self defense and the fact that sometimes we must kill for supplies and even says that they understand it, to not become so depressed. Another thing is during the day, sometimes there are events in which a survivor has the choice to leave the base and help an NPC out. It would be nice to add another choice to go with them, perhaps for an extra reward where you can physically help them out, such as clearing rubble, fixing up a base, healing people etc. (You could see it as a minigame during the day).

All in all, I really recommend this game and I believe there is also room for improvement. If you're even thinking about it, buy it. You will not regret the decision and the replayability immense, with the difficulty changing every single time.

reviewText:
I've had this game for a while and I still love it, which can't be said for a lot of games.

Not only are the visuals aesthetially pleasing, they also fit the theme of the game really well. Every single time I play, I go through every single emotion imaginable. The way individual events play with your heart and how each character has their own storyline and what makes it even better is that at the end, it's not an immediate cut off; you're told what happens to them after the ceasefire. This game is one of the most dramatic, exciting and heart wrenching games on the market and is worth every penny.

Not only that, there's an additional DLC that you can buy which adds artwork to the game and the money goes to charity (you can also decide how much you spend, to a certain extent).

However, there are a few things that I would like to see improved in the future as I believe it was touched on but not competely developed. Each character has a certain personality, explained in their biography. When certain events happen, their biography is updated with how they feel about the situation that happened, for example, if you choose to kill an NPC for supplies, some don't care while others actually do. What bothers me is that even though certain characters aren't affected by these, they still become sad, depressed and broken, leaving them completely useless. I would expect a character that actually understands the concept of self defense and the fact that sometimes we must kill for supplies and even says that they understand it, to not become so depressed. Another thing is during the day, sometimes there are events in which a survivor has the choice to leave the base and help an NPC out. It would be nice to add another choice to go with them, perhaps for an extra reward where you can physically help them out, such as clearing rubble, fixing up a base, healing people etc. (You could see it as a minigame during the day).

All in all, I really recommend this game and I believe there is also room for improvement. If you're even thinking about it, buy it. You will not regret the decision and the replayability immense, with the difficulty changing every single time.

reviewText:
I'm not really a patriotic kind, but this game makes me feel proud it was made in my country.

You can't say that TWoM is fun. It's sad, and sometimes you feel the pain of being hopeless hits you straight in the head from your computer screen. Although the gameplay may be a little repetitive, it's hard to leave this filthy in-game world. I started playing at 9 pm, the game crashed at 2:30 am and I decided to check if my progress was saved... turned off my PC three hours later. I felt proud when I upgraded my stove, then I felt guilty for killing an innocent man just to get food. And when the war was over, I felt relieved, but also hungry for more (no matter how cruel this sounds because of the main topic of this game). So it goes, as one wise man once said.

As I mentioned before, sometimes the game crashes, so some fixes are needed. Also the characters' movement is glitchy from time to time, especially when someone's running after you. I didn't really notice any other problems; TWoM looks good and its sketchy backgrounds are nicely done. I also think the music fits the gameplay perfectly.

If you're looking for a unique war experience, so different from what we, gamers, are used to - don't hesitate. In my opinion, this one-of-a-kind game is worth it. And don't forget to buy the DLC as that's the way they should be done.

Dobra robota, chłopaki.

reviewText:
It began no different than any other day... Typical morning coffee and donut on the way to the bottomless pit of work. Texting the wife to see how her day is moving along. Trying not to fall asleep to the droning voice of my mouth-breathing boss. The petty checking of emails we pretend make us important to society... It was all just a mind-numbing, typical day...
Then the sirens started.
In the distance I could hear the bombs detonating across the city. I myself was amongst the masses of the paniced city, each of us struggling to get past one another in a feudal attempt to find our families. Each street blurred in my vision as I sprinted ever faster to try and reach home. I could already see the looting beginning out of the corner of my eyes. I seen mothers with children getting trampled. Fathers shot trying to pick their families back up again. I wondered of my own family. I hadn't been a faithful man, but I was praying this day. Inside I knew, there was no home left. There was no wife. There was no daughter. All I could have truly prayed for... was the bombs hit them before the looters made their way.

It's now been a week since this war began. I couldn't even tell you why it started, or even who started it. All I see are uniforms; be it the soldiers of a standing army or the gangs of looters, even a trader that stops by my three story pile of ♥♥♥♥ we call home. Well, the three of us; Our ♥♥♥♥-heap we call home.

It took a few nights of scavenging to get us situated. I can only carry so much in one backpack. You can't expect much when you have to stay to the shadows to avoid getting shot down by a sniper. There's no doc to pry a bullet from me, and I can't say I trust this 'good cook' of ours to remove it either. The real problem though began only yesterday...

Many of the places we had decided to send me had been cut off due to heavy fighting. What was left had already been picked clean in previous nights to help us get this shanty up and running. We needed materials for weapons, food, workbenches, stoves, anti-biotics - you name it, we need it. With most of it done, it was now just a matter of keeping food and water on the table. Since our trader friend failed to show for the last two days, the fighting restricted where I could go, and our traps had been barren of any rats; we were left with one option...

The ruined house was nice, for what it's worth in this war-torn time. I was peering through the keyhole and looking at the couple and their son moving inside their home. They weren't leaving the main room, and there was no other way in. I barged through the door, and started sifting through as much as I could. I knew I had to push past them and make it to their food supply, likely in the kitchen (old habits die hard I learned). The son was of a different mind... I couldn't fault him, we all would have done the same. I can still here the click of my pistols trigger as two bullets released into the misty night air. The echo of gunfire stinging my ears from being fired indoors... The dark despair and pain settling on the parents eyes. I wondered if this is how my daughter laid before my wife. Reaching out for mommy to help her... Mommy knowing she couldn't, and our daughter just...

I swallowed the bile rising in my throat. It was the first man I ever killed. I always saw it in the games and the movies... but this was different. He didn't scream. He didn't cry out... He just tried to reach for his parents with his shakey hand while his breathing slowly gave way. I couldn't bear to watch the scene any longer, and decided it was best to move in for the food and leave before dawn came. So I did. I took the last of their food, which was hardly more than five meals for my three friends and I. I charged out of the house as quickly as I could. I heard the father whispering under his breath... Kill me...please" as I pushed back outside.

I killed a man... I killed a family... so we could all live for one more morning. My crew was thankful... but I wasn't. They weren't there to witness what I had to do for the meals... They didn't see the eyes of the hopeless. They just saw their next meal
date: their life being extended for another day or two... I can't ever forget what I saw; I saw this war of mine become more of a reality. I saw how a desperate man places more value on his life
hoursPlayed: than anothers...  I saw the barrel of my .45\n\n10/10 Wouldn't know if I could steal from them again."

reviewText:
The survivor hold their hunger while scavenging for whatever pieces they could eat or use again.
Meanwhile, I'm safely contend behind the display, eating my warm meal. Watching my survivor starving.

I'm a cruel person.

Having enough being the guy that got ordered to shoot the badguy and capture the objective?
Now try playing from the perspective of the people who's in the war, but not fighting.
This War of Mine

That said, this little game is just perfect.
Management-complexity wise is not easy, but also not impossible. Mosf of the time your survivor will starve, but that's ok as long as their not dead. :p
The day-night gameplay cycle also complement the game's survival theme. Prioritize between lot of space to bring stuff home, or bring some gun and armor to clear the scavenging location from the enemy.
Morale and Killing system here holds the player to not become a murderer spree and cold hearted b@stard/b1tch, unless you risk your survivor having mental breakdown, escaping from your shelter, or worst... suicide.
Your survivor, when enough material/supply have been gathered, can build crude facilities to support their daily struggle, like Water container, Small plantation for food, or Tool Workshop and many other. Other's will see use if you come across some specific scavenging location.. Few facility are for late game, to produce currency item to trade. Knowing which facility is for, will help greatly in your survival.

If you have completed 1 playthrough, now try again with fewer survivor, harsher climate, more dangerous war flow, and choosing hard location.
Let's see if you can survive.

reviewText:
I would rate TWoM about a 7 out of 10 - This could easily be a 9 or even 10 out of 10 however I have to deduct some points for reasons listed below.

Procedural - Well... to be honest this game can only be called procedural with the barest bones of random elements. Dont be fooled into thinking every play through will be 'completely' different. There are approx 20 different locations you can scavenge and they always look the same. They have the same layout, cabinets etc are always in the same place. Only the contents vary somewhat (a cabinet may hold food and wood in one play and parts and wood in another). As to what will happen when you go there: every location has one of two possible events/scenarios at that location. Pretty barebones with the random element if you ask me...

Also survivors - There are basically 5 main survivors you can control, but they are always the same and have the same strengths/weaknesses every time.

Overall content - There just isnt enough that you can craft, harvest or build. Not by a long shot. No matter what 'random' scenario you have in your game you will always end up visiting the same locations in roughly the same order (by order of threat) and always building and upgrading the minimal amount of upgrades in roughly the same order of priority.

Despite the poor amount of overall content and procedural randomness I would still recommend this game (during a sale) as it shines when it comes down to gameplay and emotional attachment of characters. Some decisions you make can really weigh on your mind haha.

I havent really browsed the workshop as yet but this is one of those games that is very much worth playing, but could have been truly outstanding if it just had 'more'.

Great game, but because i dont know what more to say, i will instead share the recipe of some blueberry pancakes

1 1/4 cups all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon salt

1 tablespoon baking powder

1 1/4 teaspoons white sugar

1 egg

1 cup milk

1/2 tablespoon butter, melted

1/2 cup frozen blueberries, thawed



In a large bowl, sift together flour, salt, baking powder and sugar. In a small bowl, beat together egg and milk. Stir milk and egg into flour mixture. Mix in the butter and fold in the blueberries. Set aside for 1 hour.

Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

reviewText:
This War of Mine involves a group of civilians who take shelter in a damaged and war-torn building in an attempt to survive the horrors of a besieged city in war-time. You control the group of survivors who are struggling to survive and it is your duty to ensure that they do, no matter what it takes.

Pros:
+ Beautiful graphics: illustrates war to perfection through visual themes.

+ Realistic gameplay: Decisions made WILL impact the group and affect them in different ways.

+ Each survivor has their own 'ability' and 'trait': For example, Bruno is a good cook and will use less supplies to cook meals. But, he is also a smoker, so he enjoys cigarettes and can rely on them to restore bad moods. Thus, meaning that you will be tempted to gather cigarettes when scavenging.

+ Trading: Different civilians in the city will value supplies differently, depending on their needs. Very realistic.

+ Emotive: This War of Mine does a fantastic job in making you feel guilty if you make an evil decision to gain supplies.

+ Random events: Some days, people will come to your front door requesting assistance. This adds another realistic aspect and requires some decision making about whether or not to help them. These also happen during scavenging, as you can sometimes find people being attacked by military at some locations and you can decide whether or not to help them. There are consequences to every action you make.

+ Risks: Mostly, everything is a risk. From scavanging at night and potentially being killed, from sending out a group member to help someone. You either reap the rewards or regret accepting the mission.

+ Mood effects: Your surviviors can become depressed if you do too many evil acts, such as stealing or not helping people. An example of this would be killing someone for supplies, the group will learn of this act and have different opinions on it, such as not caring at all or feeling responsible. The killer is also impacted, as they can even commit suicide through guilt if you're not careful. Some survivors can even steal from you and leave the shelter if they become unhappy. However, making good decisions like helping civilians will boost your survivors morale and ensure they stay at the shelter.

+ Night: The night is done to perfection. You can only send one survivor out to scavenge to ruins of the city while the rest can either sleep or stay on guard. There is also a chance of people raiding your shelter and stealing supplies or even killing/wounding your survivors, depending on how well you have fortified your shelter. This adds a great deal of tension to the following mornings after scavenging as you may be left without any supplies.

+ Construction: There is a vast array of many different things to construct in the game, such as vegetable gardens, rainwater collectors and alarm systems. You will always be making decisions about which thing you need to construct the most and will utilise the night scavenging and traders to gather the exact supplies you need and could end up ignoring food and medicine for these parts.

+ Replay value: The game does a good job in encouraging you to replay the game with different survivors and see how you fare. Want a challenge? Start in winter.

+ Implementation of seasons: In winter, you use a lot more resources in keeping your survivors warm. If you do not, your survivors can freeze to death the following morning or become terminally ill from disease spreading.

+ Perfect attention to detail: Simple aspects such as having ill survivors sleeping next to healthy survivors WILL increase the chance of them becoming ill, which I think is a great touch by the developers to add into This War of Mine. Furthermore, adding things like your survivors running slower or becoming depressed if they are wounded/ill is a brilliant touch and is often overlooked.

+ Shelter layout: The shelter is completely under your control other than the workbench and fridge and YOU decide where everything is built. This can be utilised well or not at all, depending on the player.

+ Large amounts of locations: Night scavenging opens up a variety of different locations for the player to explore, such as hospitals (with doctors working there who can heal you) ruined schools and even military outposts.

+ Soundtrack: The game's soundtrack suits the game really well, as it tends to be quite eerie music most of the time: especially at night.

+ Bugs: There are next to no bugs I encountered whilst playing this game and all the bugs that were found are quickly patched.

+ Price: The game is also fairly cheap to buy at around £15, compared to most games nowadays costing around £30-£40.

Cons:
- No statistics: This could've been added to make the game almost perfect, as a lot of people (including myself) like to have stats in games telling them, for example, how many overall days they've survived, how many people they've killed etc.

- Late game: Near the end of the game, it does become tedious when you have built everything and are skipping days just to get to the ending.

- Achievements: The achievements do not tell you how to aquire them and require a lot of trial and error to obtain. Some people may like this, however pefectionists may find it to be frustrating at times.

- No difficulty settings: The entire game is based on one difficulty. This does limit the game as people can find it to be quite easy and would prefer it to be more difficult, like less supplies to scavenge.

Overall, This War of Mine is a fantastic survival-based game which will thrill you into playing it to death (no pun intended). It utilises the concepts of war and how devastating it can be to engage the player at all times. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys survival-based games or emotive games that will affect the player's mood, which is uncommon in most games today.

reviewText:
You start off with a group of survivors, stuck in a dirt hole of a house
barely held together by wood and cloth.
Gunfire and explosions can be heard close by, but that's the least of your worries.
You have a handful of tools, some wood and some food that might last you for the day,
and there seems to be no end in sight to the war.

A major milestone, It's more of an experience rather than a game.

This War of Mine drops every single money-making aspect of AAA games in the market and provides a totally new perspective in war. The graphics are dark and gritty without being boring, the music is sad and slow yet hopeful. The gameplay is slow and, on paper, is simple.. but the way everything is packaged, provides the most unique gaming experiences ever.

reviewText:
This game is hard, without a doubt. From the perspective of suffering civilians, This War of Mine is something you typically set out to play for the survival tactic and the interesting change of story; the portrayal of not soldiers, but the lesser-seen gameplay of civilians in war-strewn cities.
The connections grown with each individual character and their situation grow stronger and stronger throughout the game. Reading their growing biography with every passing day, seeing their moods alter based off of current events. If needs for supplies are not met in time, the death impacts everything and it really is powerful. I'm honestly excited to see how The Little Ones DLC plays out and curious to see how it effects the overall gameplay.

The atmosphere itself is powerful as well, with an art style that is both aesthetically pleasing but suiting the core aspect of the game; the grimy, cold struggle for survival. The music is the most fitting (and indisputably catchy) music possible. Everything about this game is beautiful and terrible, and I love it. Would recommend to anyone.

reviewText:
If you like zombie-survival games or just like the survival concept then you'll probably love this game.
The searching system works a little bit like State of Decay, but I like this game way more.
The game is based on real life, i.e. if you ignore people who knock on the door for some medicin, your squad (often) gets depressed/broken.
Also if you kill/rob people your squad will probably get sad, this'll affect the gameplay.
(I.e. if people are broken they won't be able to do anything and you will need to feed/heal them)


So yeah, I recommend the game and look forward for updates!

reviewText:
You start off with a group of survivors, stuck in a dirt hole of a house
barely held together by wood and cloth.
Gunfire and explosions can be heard close by, but that's the least of your worries.
You have a handful of tools, some wood and some food that might last you for the day,
and there seems to be no end in sight to the war.

A major milestone, It's more of an experience rather than a game.

This War of Mine drops every single money-making aspect of AAA games in the market and provides a totally new perspective in war. The graphics are dark and gritty without being boring, the music is sad and slow yet hopeful. The gameplay is slow and, on paper, is simple.. but the way everything is packaged, provides the most unique gaming experiences ever.

reviewText:
There is one run in particular where I have to share my story on this interesting game.

When you are on the brink of collapsing you gotta do what you gotta do. I stole from the homeless, and no one gave a ♥♥♥♥. I then stole from the hospital, and everyone starts to question my morality. WTF? I then kill someone chasing me with a knife and everybody is starting to give up. You got to be kidding me. But even after all of this ridiculousness, I still tried my best to help everyone the best that I could.

And that is what this game does well. It really immerses you into the setting, and has you try your best to get these people through the horror of war. You start to take a liking to some of the characters, and you want them to push through. I had to make some difficult and unethical decisions along the way. However, all of these aspects kept me coming back for more.

reviewText: Fantastic.  Yes, it does get a wee bit repetitve after a couple weeks into the experience, but even that helps the immersion in my opinion.  The game relies heavily on your application of imagination and willingness to role play.  I love games that drop you into the world and you provide your own story.  Do you want to be ruthless or go hungry to avoid hitting that one untouched locale with good people just trying to survive?  Do you intervene when people in the world are victimized or take a better you than me" approach and go about your business while the bad folks are distracted?\n\nIt's very much a sim and not a typical war game.  I enjoy it immensely
date: but once again I'll warn you that the game expects you to bring something to the table to maximize your expeience.  The random nature of the game also allows for a great amount of replay value.\n\nA bargain at 20 bucks.  Do it."

reviewText:
This game is an amazingly immersive experience. I got totally shrecked the first 4-5 times I played it before I started to become more familiar with the mechanics and how to survive. I made it through the winter and into the spring time when the war finally came to a close around about 60 days in or so. I was absolutely hooked on this game, I didn't want to stop playing it until I'd beaten it. And to be honest, when I finally did beat it I was a little bit sad that it was over. But at the same time, I was happy for my fictional in-game characters. They wouldn't have to do those despicable things to survive anymore. The ♥♥♥♥, murder, and pilaging was over. And then I sat in my desk chair for several minutes contemplating everything I'd done in those 60 days to survive. Thinking about how those things really happened to REAL people back in the seige of Sarajevo during the Bosnian war in the 90's. I've never played a video game that made me think about real life(...and death) such as This War of Mine.

10 out of 10, would recommend. To anyone. Play this game now, before you forget about it. Also, don't be put off by the difficulty at first. After an hour or two of playing you will be a lot better at surviving guaranteed.

Shout outs to all who had to go through the seige of Sarajevo. I know This War of Mine is just a game, but it's a game that gave me a MUCH MUCH greater respect for ANYONE who's gone through such a terrible war and had to get their hands dirty to survive. And to those who did all that they could to help other innocent civilians while putting their own lives at risk.

reviewText: This War of Mine is amazing. It has the old ‘just one more turn’ quality common to games like Civilisation and as a consequence will consistently keep you up well into the morning hours. The game is defined by several layers of play, all of which fit seamlessly together in forming a deeply moving and often ‘emotionally taxing’ experience.\nThe first layer-of-play is orientated around exploration and scavenging in which you will be called upon to move, point-and-click style, three protagonists around your base and various other environments in search of building materials, food and weapons. The second layer-of-play is the crafting system in which you will be called upon to manage supplies, upgrade equipment and maintain existing infrastructure in the bombed-out apartment block you call home. The third layer is defined by character management in which you will have to carefully maintain the physical and psychological health of your characters through the provision of food, supplies and entertainment. The forth layer involves the strategic map which allows you to journey to other locations around the besieged city, collect supplies and interact with various realistically depicted NPCs. The fifth layer manifests as a very intense platform-based stealth system which allows you to kill, sneak and steal in various environments. The sixth layer is defined by an emergent morality system in which both NPCs and your characters react realistically to your actions, lamenting death, cursing murder and ultimately resorting to begging and sadism under different circumstances. The seventh and final layer involves interacting with NPCs for trade and barter.\nAll of these layers-of-play blend together extremely well, providing a highly immersive experience. The game makes you truly feel like you are a survivor on the brink and demands much in the way of emotional fortitude when you put your characters in harms’ way. I cannot recommend this game enough. 10/10.

reviewText:
The game has you managing your supplies by determining who gets to eat, and who gets medical treatment if sick. Gathering supplies from outside (Only at night since it’s safer) has you putting your home at risk from looters if not properly protected. Also building improvements like barricades, beds, booking facilities, moonshine stills, all help to keep your civilians alive. Even keeping the house warm with a stove becomes imperative, when deciding to use fuel for either cooking or heating.

The game has no tutorial or instructions on what the best approach is, rather it’s left up to you. Do you want to survive? Help others? Become bandits and rob others? Even take part in the war by attacking military posts. All rather difficult tasks, and none really goes through as planned.

My game started off with three young men, Marko, Bruno, and Pavle. Bruno was the cook who feared venturing out, caring only for survival. With the mentality, better them than us. Marko and Pavle the strongest of the two as far as scavenging and defending. As the game progressed I ran into an elderly man named Anton who excelled in creating items and gave him shelter.

The game has you investing in your characters and fabricating their personalities in your mind as you make choices that put them at risk. Towards the end of my game winter sets in and supplies become scarce, while sickness becomes more common. Pavle ends up dying trying to back home through Snipers alley, an obvious reason why it’s called that. Marko dies trying to steal supplies from bandits that own a brothel. Left with a sick Anton and the cowardly Bruno. I set Bruno to avenge Marko as a last ditch effort. I imagined Bruno having lost his fear in desperation and anger. Making him kill three armed men with a shovel as he ambushed them from different locations of their hideout. The risk brought in a big reward.

However returning home he only found that Anton froze to death in his bed. Bruno was now alone, suffering depression, but getting what he wanted from the start, just to survive.

reviewText:
People can barely understand how good of a game this is...

So get this:
1. You feel your people. You form deep bonds with them.
2. You care for them, as if they are your children.
3. If something happens, it affects you. Like yeah, it hits you right in the middle of your chest.
4. If you feel a lump in your throat if someone dies: it is perfectly natural.

Play this game people, and learn from it. It is the thought that counts. Nobody knows what our future would be like, but it may turn out to be just like that. If so, you would be a tad better prepared, and live to tell the tale.

So much feeling, horror, tight moments, love and passion all wrapped up into one little game.

You cannot deprive yourself the experience. Truly.

reviewText:
This game is so sad. I don't mean that in a negative way, either. It forces you to make tough decisions. Will you try and play the righteous path, where you barter and trade with your neighbors? Good.

However, what if the trader doesn't have what you need at the moment? You don't want to let your group starve, do you? Well let's go scavenge a nearby building for food and supplies. You sneak into the structure, gathering food and building materials to just try and get you buy. You aren't taking everything, heck, you can't even carry that much.

As you're searching through the cabinets for the canned goods and medicine you need, a hostile opens the door to your right and attempts to unload a magazine of ammunition at you. Through quick thinking, you descend down the stairs and wait for him in the dark corner so you can achieve the element of surprise on your well armed oppenent. He rounds the corner, and you stab him until he collapses onto the floor with a gurgling thud. You begin looting his ammunition when you hear more footsteps descending down the stairs. You ready yourself for the second onslaught, but it passes you by an collapses on your former opponents corpse into a sobbing heap. When the red haze of bloodlust clears, you realize that it was an elderly man and his wife. She moans uncontrollably and laments the fact that her love is now gone. He wasn't a hostile looter, he was an elderly man in a secluded building trying to make sure no one stole his sick wifes medication.

You then have an epiphany. You realize that he wasn't an evil doer bent on ending your life. You realize that you, in fact, are the bandit.

Edit: Before the trolls come out from under their bridges, no this actual scenario doesn't happen in the game. I wrote a short fictional story to avoid spoilers. This TYPE of thing does happen, however.

reviewText: Truly, what an amazing game this is! I've been sucked in for well over 12 hours in one sitting, something that very rarily happens for me with an indie game like this. (The play-time counter is broken for some reason...) The soundtrack is really good, it perfectly illustrates the doubt and fear in this group of survivors you're trying to lead. The gritty art style is very, very nicely done. The sketchy look and dull, grey colors do a really good job of showing this ravaged urban area. The stealth system is quite advanced, and the combat is random and really nervewracking (Think of XCOM). Losing a beloved member of the group is really a deep pain, and it echoes throughout the group. They mourn their dead and might even become depressed. The looting is very rewarding, and the limited inventory space forces heavy inventory management. Nothing like sneaking through a bandit camp and stealing all the goods that they themselves have stolen from others. The trading is very fun and well done, and it forces a lot of tough decisions. Do I want tobacco/alcohol that I may be able to sell for a good amount of food/materials, or do I want to just bring a smaller amount of materials or food and avoid the risk of not being able to sell it when I need food the most? The decisions you have to make are tough. I found myself robbing an elderly couple in pure desperation, only to stop for a moment and realize what I'd just done. The game has good replayability to a point, as it's somewhat randomized.\n\nAll in all, one of the best, if not very best, survival indie games I have ever played. 10/10, would starve to death again.

reviewText:
A really great game, every action that you take makes you take a second and think about it. The characters make you feel regret if you steal or murder others to survive. When I played this game, I felt as if I were struggling with them.

Early on I was scared of everybody, people who knocked on my door, people where you could scavage. However, as you continue to play, you realize that everybody is trying to survive as well. Some may want to help, some may need help, and some are just thugs trying to get by. There's a reason for every action that takes place in this game, and the developers have done an amazing job on simulating the emotion and issues that these characters face.

For example, when I was running low on everything, I decided to scavage the quiet home. There were only 2 people in that house, an elderly couple who could not fight back. They pleaded for mercy, they had many materials, but everytime I would loot something, the old man would beg for me to leave and to not raid them. I felt bad raiding their things, knowing that they would perish because of my actions. I tried to ignore it, however when I got back to the safehouse, every member had judged me. They were mentioning how cruel the character I controlled was, because I had stolen from a defenseless couple.

This game however could improve a little on its story and variety. Sometimes you feel as if it's hopeless, or that you're not getting anywhere. The cost of crafting neccessities may be a bit high sometimes, and can cause problems even after you've gathered enough supplies.

This is a definite purchase, even for its price.

8.5/10

reviewText: So this guy knocks on my door wanting to come inside. I don't know who he is kidding like I'm some noob about to feed him. I promptly slammed the door in his face and didn't even listen to his rebuttal. Later I crept up the tower at some army base and stabbed the soldier in his back. His buddies came running before falling. I decided to leave a few soldiers to guard the rest of my treasure. Everyone was happy back at the crib lounging about on sofas, smoking cigarrettes, drinking moonshine, enjoying their coffee, growing hydroponics, reading dirty mags, listening to the radio, and playing the guitar. It's such a party every single night around here. I hear others were having a hard time. I've looted the ones I came across. Some guy was begging me for food the other night I had 5 chicken dinners on the stove and 20 cans of meat but I just lolled. I mean really? This war is mine. It's dog eat dog out here kid. I feel for ya I really do that's why I always keep a woman around to console me. As soon as I get in the door I stick my whole face on her bossom to ease the pain.

reviewText: Its almost entirely about resource management. Due to the mouse driven controls, the actual combat is a bit unwieldy, so I didn't resort to it much. reviewText:
This game is absolutely brutal, and unforgiving.  As a trio of civilians living in shell of a house, you start from scratch and essentially progress through the game by gradually improving your hideout, as you simultaneously stave off disease, depression, looters and hunger.  Balancing all of these competing threats is significantly easier said than done.

The game really evokes the grim reality of a modern war, in both its art style and gameplay.  Losing one of your civilians is actually quite emotionally profound; each civilian ha their own backstory and specific skill, but also hopes and dreams, as well as interesting quirk (e.g. smokes, or enjoys reading).  Keeping them alive is tough, but in my first playthrough it was not disease or depression that killed my poor family, but blundering into armed thugs and being shot for their troubles.  As inglorious and abrupt as these ends were, it didn't break the immersion whatsoever; people die in stupid ways in war.  What's more, the civilian deaths deeply affect your fellow characters, severely depressing them.  Let this go unattended for too long, and they may commit suicide.  Brutal.

As wonderfully depressing and harsh as this game is (and long; a dev. commentary stated that the war could progress for as long as mere weeks to months!), I did feel that the weapon, and shooting, mechanics could be explained a little better.  I don't really know when the best situations are to use firearms, how to acquire all the necessary parts or even how to use them.  BUT, this is a minor complaint, and reflective of the fact i chose to ignore firearms completely in favour of scavenging as much as I could peacefully, then getting the hell outa there.

All in all, a really emotionally profound game thats incredibly depressing, and tough to play for extended periods of time.  I highly recommend it!!

reviewText:
I think its the Papers Please of this year. It combines equal parts of aformentioned Papers Please, State of Decay, and I Am Alive. It shows how war isn't a good thing. People die. People get hurt. Families are torn appart. War IS bad.
It also has some pretty solid AI. Rather, the AI is random, per say. There is no set currency, no set money system, no set value. It all depends on who you are trading with.
How the AI reacts to you is based on logic. An old person didnt attack me while i was looting his house because i had a knife, while a dude blew my brains out because I was near his ill mother.
The base building is solid,too. This is my base. There are many like it, but this is mine.
I really dig the graphics. Some times its a bit hard to make out stuff, but i love it for this all the more.
Anyway, this is the short version. Maybe i'll add a longer version, but if you take away nothing else from this review, take away this:This game is one of the best games to come out this year. I wouldn't doubt it'll overtake any number of GoTY canidates, and it sure as hell did overtake mine. Sorry, Wolf Amoung Us.

reviewText:
This War of Mine could be called the offspring of DayZ and XCOM: Enemy Unknown (whose older sister was The Sims), both excellent games that are strategic, tense and merciless. But beyond that, nearly all simularities end, unless you play This War of Mine.

This aptly named title, is a 2D survival game where you control a group of survivors, holed up in a shabby cottage-like structure, trying to ignore the horrors of the war going on outside and focus on living.

Your first (in-game) day is essentially getting your cottage ready, you will need to get rid of rubble, grab all the supplies still within, and create furniture for your home. Sounds kinda like the Sims, right? Yeah, well, throw the idea of not letting your Sims eat food out the window now, because it gets merciless from here.

The night (much like most survival games) is where the true danger is at. You are going to exhaust your supplies pretty quickly unless you go out scavenging, so it is essential you go out and collect more supplies. This is where night comes in. At night, you want to select what your party is going to be doing for the remainder of the night. Do they guard, sleep, sleep in beds, or scavenge? I generally had 1 guarding, 1-2 sleeping on beds (you have to make the beds, so don't expect them to be happy if you don't have them) and 1 scavenging. The person you have got scavenging is the only person you will control for the rest of the night.

You select the site in which your scavenger will... scavenge. He/she will be controlled by you for the remainder of the night. Considering it is your first night, chances are, you have no weapons, no lockpicks, nothing. Just you, your wits and your stealth ability.

You start to enter the house, slowly creeping around to make sure no one that might be in the house hears you.
You scrounge around in a few cupboards, not a lot.
That's when you see it: The icon that shows a hand reaching for a diamond.

Do you want to take from private property? Do you want to take from people? Do you want to become a bandit?

You take it, feeling guilty for your actions, and continue on.

You make it back only just in time, before dawn so you could get home without a Sniper seeing you.

Then, as if last night wasn't stressful enough: You've been raided. Your guard is wounded.

You now have to take the time to nurse to him, sort your supplies, build all the things you need and countless other things.

You start doing your work when you hear a knock on the door.

A kid wants your help, he has no more medicine to tend to his mother and pleads for your help.

It is up to you to decide all these moral choices, but there will always be a consequence for your actions. You may have done the right thing, but you lost some valuable supplies. You turned them down because you need them, but now your survivors are doubting their situation.

I may have described the typical night, but you still need to address your teams morale, cook food, and so on.

Actions such as killing people and stealing from helpless affect your team's emotions, sometimes causing PTSD. It is good to see a game take killing so seriously, it isn't done too often. Their emotions can cause them to degrade others, stop being motivated in doing their tasks, and even making them leave your group. It is something you always need to think about before taking action.

Time moves interestingly in this game. Time will move 10 minutes about every 15 or so seconds. Once it reaches 8 PM, it transits into your night duties. During the night, you need to get out of there by 4:30 AM, otherwise you may not make it back. You can end both day and night early if you feel that you will be wasting time waiting. But time is of essence and you must use it wisely for your survival.

The art-style consists of very little colour, with a lot of pencil detail. While it does a good job at setting the dreary mood, I did think it could have been a bit more lush and vibrant, and it can get a little straining on the eyes.

Although it has good icons and controls so you get the hang of it pretty quickly, This War of Mine does lack a strong tutorial. While something can be said of realism and throwing you in the deep-end, I do feel that some people might struggle initially.

It is rather hard to describe this game, because it's a game that is rather new in concept, a rather surprising sight considering the recent popularity of survival games.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game, everything is thought out and all the ideas have been well executed on. It could do with some improvements, but this game does a fantastic job at showing the horrors of war in an engaging way, while also proving to still have solid game mechanics. It is a must buy for any fan of the survivalist/war-story genres.

8.5 out of 10.

reviewText: Big at heart, but shallow on content. TWoM is an artistically ambitious game, with some amazing and stark visual effects, but after a few plays through you'll find yourself at the bottom of the content barrel. The general tone, capturing the enui of living day-to-day life in a war zone, is captured beautifully, while the crafting system and world exploration system are both imaginative. You'll just want more after 20 hours or so. One pickadillo: the English is a little wonky in certain bits of dialog, and even awkward English aside, the dialog could be much better fleshed out. It's like a 3.5/5 stars, but try it anyways if for no other reason that it's an entirely unique concept.

reviewText: The only game to ever make me regret or feel sorrowful for the decisions I made. I loved and dreaded every minute of it. I loved the game itself and I spent the whole time planning and wondering what my next move would be. I hate loved how it made me so upset at times and put me through so much stress, but it was a great experience. I survived for 45 days on my first attempt making it through the war. My first four died, three to a combat system I wasn't entirely prepared for and one to a silly misclick. But my last four survived, those final days were the most stressful as I had to balance the food and ended it with 3 being very hungry and 1 starving!! In the end I will always find playability and I won't lie and say I didn't tear up a bit at the end when it reminded me of all my actions and those who had passed. Retelling the story and then giving me what happened to those who lived.\n\nTL:DR Buy this ♥♥♥♥ing game if you want an emotional and phsycological trip into one of those most real games I've ever played.

reviewText:
A supremely atmospheric and emotionally daunting experience.

After playing more than once in a single sitting I felt emotionally exhausted, much like the characters in the game. Not to mention the other survivors opinions on what you did, I won't soon forget coming back to the house and reeling as Pavle sat dead still after his actions during the nights scavenge.

Do yourself a favour and spend the money to support the studio. They've done an excellent job with this title and I'll be damn sure to reccommend it to my friends.

reviewText:
Bought it because I enjoy survival games and it was on sale.

I was hesitant about it at first because I read it was a side-scroller, and I've found a lot of those to be a bit boring,  but I've quickly become addicted to it. I haven't had any major problems with it besides one small glitch with something I'd constructed not registering when clicked on, but everything else has run smoothly. The characters and their reactions to the world around them are entirely realistic, and I have become invested in their personal stories. I wish there were some different homes, or more challenges that would present themselves, because it would be fun to break out of the habits you inevitably fall in to when replaying. Maybe a significantly longer war?

Overall, I think it's fine the way it is, and I've really enjoyed playing it over and over again.

reviewText: The gamei is miserably depressing, which is good because thats exactly what the game is trying to do. A survival game were you look for resources and try to stay alive in a war torn city.\nYou will struggle, your people will be murdered in raids, or on scanveger runs, they will die of sickness.\nThe game is very simple to play but also has enough complexity to keep you going for a few hours.

reviewText:
So you usually play the soldier, buisy killing what ever moves around, and your to buisy killing to realize what are the real consequances of war. In this game the tables are turned and you are a cevilian, trying to survive the war inflicted upon you by ruthless soldiers, who will kill you in a blink of an eye. But not only that, you will also have to take on basic challanges of survivel, like getting food and water, keeping yourself from falling into deep depression, deffending your home from invaders who want to rob you and take advantage of your posessions. The game also deals with the harsh reality of war by confronting you with hard and even brutal desicions you have to make in order to survive, like for example robing old peoples houses to get food, refusing to shelter people to save on food or maybe shelter them to gain strength against potential robers and attackers. You also have a trading & crafting system ingame, both of are which are complex and well done. You should listen to the radio not only to keep your sanity, but also to update on what kind of currency is up right now, for example maybe cigaretes are scarce right now and worth more, maybe its coffee. I can go on on about possibilities in this game since there are all over the place, this game is all about choices. every game you'll start will play trough differently, making the game highly replayable. The chracter are well thought off, everyone has its own personality, with strengths a background, and stuff they like, ehich can help you maintain their sanity by providing them with those stuff. There is a lot of stealth involved as you need to snick trough peoples houses to loot, or avoid trigger happy soldiers and snipers. You also have a combat system, in which you can use weapons you crafted to raid places and kill opponents.

I love the graphics, which really portrait the feeling of your chracters, showing their exhaustion, sadness, hunger. If your chracter is a smoker or a reader youll find animations of them taking use of your inventory to keep them sain, smoking drinking coffee maybe reading a book. The other cevilians and characters are also excellent. The art direction and animations are beautiful.

You will find yourself caring for your chracters, and reading about the moral issues they are facing, which is really the point of the game, showing you what war is really about, its about making choices inflicted upon you by a harsh reality.

Voice acting would of brought this game to another level.
Also since this is an indie platformer i dont compare it to high budget games since it would'nt be fair.

As an indie platformer game i give it a 8 out of 10. would be 9 with voice acting

reviewText:
I'm currently at work writing this review and I must say that I'm not feeling good today, thinking about going home really.  I didn't really have much coffee this morning, the scones my boss supplies didn't look appetizing, and I'm just in a generally negative mood.

You see, last night as I was playing, This War of Mine, I was extremely desperate to save my four survivors who were wounded, sick, and on the brink of starvation.  I was so desperate that I ended up breaking into a house and began looting it.  I heard footsteps, and hid in a corner.  As the intruder came closer I pulled out my axe and jumped the intruder from behind.  I hacked down a little boy with my axe, his sobbing mother who came to his side, and eventually the father who fell next to his family.

I truly feel like a piece of ♥♥♥♥ in real life right now, not sure how I'm going to recover.  The sobbing mom next to the little boy as I hacked her from the back was enough....I may take a little break and evaluate my morale compass.

reviewText: Not a game in the usual sense of the game . . it is however stunningly good in many ways. Not must, because it's tone probably won't appeal to everyone but for it's price, it's content, it's theme and the way it portrays it and the inevitable dLc that I fervently hope they include, it definitely should be something you experience at least once . .
